description: From Middle English personable, personabil, equivalent to person +‎ -able. Compare Medieval Latin personabilis (“personal”), found in a late 13th century British source. The Middle French personable (“remarkable, important”) does not appear until 1528.

adjectives.description: personable (comparative more personable, superlative most personable)

entries.meaning: (of a person) Having a pleasing appearance; attractive; handsome.
examples: I admit him a personable man, for I have seen him; and I will suppose him courteous and agreeable.

entries.meaning: (of a person) Having a pleasant or manner; friendly; amiable.
examples: I'm bound to admit that you're a personable young rascal, with the best manners I've met in a long time.

entries.meaning: (law, obsolete) Enabled to maintain pleas in court.
examples: The Queen be by that name personable to plead
